Fatou's lemma, monotone functions

Let f(x)f\p{x}f(x) be a non-decreasing function on [0,1]\br{0, 1}[0,1]. You may assume that fff is differentiable almost everywhere.

  1. Prove that ∫01f′(x) dx≤f(1)−f(0)\int_0^1 f'\p{x} \,\diff{x} \leq f\p{1} - f\p{0}∫01​f′(x)dx≤f(1)−f(0).

    Hint: Fatou.

    Hint: Let rn(x)=∑k≥nfk(x)r_n\p{x} = \sum_{k \geq n} f_k\p{x}rn​(x)=∑k≥n​fk​(x). It is enough to show rn′(x)→0r_n'\p{x} \to 0rn′​(x)→0 a.e. Take a subsequence rnjr_{n_j}rnj​​ such that rnj(1)−rnj(0)→0r_{n_j}\p{1} - r_{n_j}\p{0} \to 0rnj​​(1)−rnj​​(0)→0 and use part (a).
Solution.

  1. For convenience, we extend fff to f(x)=f(1)f\p{x} = f\p{1}f(x)=f(1) for x≥1x \geq 1x≥1. By assumption,

    f′(x)=lim inf⁡h→0 f(x +h)−f(x)hf'\p{x} = \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{f\p{x\,+ h} - f\p{x}}{h}f′(x)=h→0liminf​hf(x+h)−f(x)​

    for almost every xxx. Hence, by Fatou's lemma and a translation change of variables,

    ∫01f′(x) dx≤lim inf⁡h→0 ∫01f(x+h)−f(x)h dx=lim inf⁡h→0 1h(∫01f(x+h) dx−∫01f(x) dx)=lim inf⁡h→0 1h(∫h1+hf(x) dx−∫01f(x) dx)=lim inf⁡h→0 1h(∫11+hf(x) dx+∫h1f(x) dx−∫01f(x) dx)=lim inf⁡h→0 1h(∫11+hf(x) dx−∫0hf(x) dx)≤lim inf⁡h→0 1h(hf(1+h)−hf(0))=lim inf⁡h→0 1h(hf(1)−hf(0))=f(1)−f(0),\begin{aligned} \int_0^1 f'\p{x} \,\diff{x} &\leq \liminf_{h\to0}\,\int_0^1 \frac{f\p{x + h} - f\p{x}}{h} \,\diff{x} \\ &= \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{1}{h} \p{\int_0^1 f\p{x + h} \,\diff{x} - \int_0^1 f\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \\ &= \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{1}{h} \p{\int_h^{1+h} f\p{x} \,\diff{x} - \int_0^1 f\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \\ &= \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{1}{h} \p{\int_1^{1+h} f\p{x} \,\diff{x} + \int_h^1 f\p{x} \,\diff{x} - \int_0^1 f\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \\ &= \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{1}{h} \p{\int_1^{1+h} f\p{x} \,\diff{x} - \int_0^h f\p{x} \,\diff{x}} \\ &\leq \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{1}{h} \p{hf\p{1 + h} - hf\p{0}} \\ &= \liminf_{h\to0}\,\frac{1}{h} \p{hf\p{1} - hf\p{0}} \\ &= f\p{1} - f\p{0}, \end{aligned}∫01​f′(x)dx​≤h→0liminf​∫01​hf(x+h)−f(x)​dx=h→0liminf​h1​(∫01​f(x+h)dx−∫01​f(x)dx)=h→0liminf​h1​(∫h1+h​f(x)dx−∫01​f(x)dx)=h→0liminf​h1​(∫11+h​f(x)dx+∫h1​f(x)dx−∫01​f(x)dx)=h→0liminf​h1​(∫11+h​f(x)dx−∫0h​f(x)dx)≤h→0liminf​h1​(hf(1+h)−hf(0))=h→0liminf​h1​(hf(1)−hf(0))=f(1)−f(0),​

    as required.

  2. Notice that because all the fnf_nfn​ are non-decreasing, it follows that FFF is non-decreasing as well. Thus, FFF is differentiable almost everywhere. Similarly, rnr_nrn​ is differentiable almost everywhere as well, for all n≥1n \geq 1n≥1.

    rn′(x)−rn+1′(x)=fn′(x)≥0,r_n'\p{x} - r_{n+1}'\p{x} = f_n'\p{x} \geq 0,rn′​(x)−rn+1′​(x)=fn′​(x)≥0,

    since fnf_nfn​ is non-decreasing. In other words, {rn′(x)}n\set{r_n'\p{x}}_n{rn′​(x)}n​ and because each fnf_nfn​ is non-decreasing,

    ∑k=nmfn′(x)≥0 ∀m  ⟹  rn′(x)≥0,\sum_{k=n}^m f_n'\p{x} \geq 0\ \forall m \implies r_n'\p{x} \geq 0,k=n∑m​fn′​(x)≥0 ∀m⟹rn′​(x)≥0,

    so rn′(x)r_n'\p{x}rn′​(x) is a monotone decreasing sequence bounded below. Thus, rn′r_n'rn′​ converges almost everywhere, so we may apply the monotone convergence theorem. Combined with (1), we have

    ∫01lim⁡n→∞rn′(x) dx=lim⁡n→∞∫01rn′(x) dx≤lim⁡n→∞(rn(1)−rn(0))=0.\int_0^1 \lim_{n\to\infty} r_n'\p{x} \,\diff{x} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \int_0^1 r_n'\p{x} \,\diff{x} \leq \lim_{n\to\infty} \p{r_n\p{1} - r_n\p{0}} = 0.∫01​n→∞lim​rn′​(x)dx=n→∞lim​∫01​rn′​(x)dx≤n→∞lim​(rn​(1)−rn​(0))=0.

    Since rn′≥0r_n' \geq 0rn′​≥0, it follows that lim⁡n→∞rn′(x)=0\lim_{n\to\infty} r_n'\p{x} = 0limn→∞​rn′​(x)=0 almost everywhere and so
